KMgram,3r i gadi e r -Ge nera 1, for Field Marshal, Commanding-in-Chief. British Armies in Prance.The Secretary,War Office,LONDON, S.W. S E C R E T.DETAILED REPORT ON BOMB RAID CARRIED OUT 11TH APRIL. 1918.12 De Havilland 4s. left the ground at 10.40 am. to bomb the Railway station and lines at LUXEMBOURG. One machine was forced to return with engine trouble at 11,30 am. without dropping his bombs. The remainder reached their objective and dropped 22 112-lb. bombs from 12,000 feet. It was very hard to observe results owing to the clouds, but one burst was seen.on the railway North of the Station, four other bursts on the Railway and one burst on an engine shed.Ten plates were exposed, which, however, were spoilt by clouds.Anti-aircraft fire was considerable, but no enemy airoraft wereseen.The lines were re-crossed at 14,000 feet over PONT-a-MOUSSON. All our machines returned safely at 2.18 p.m.Visibility was good but there were thick light clouds and a high wind.A successful Photographic Reconnaissance was carried out of the Aerodromes, Dumps, Railway Stations and Junctions to the East of METZ. 44 plates were exposed, some of which, however, were spoilt by cloud.In the Field, (Sd.) C,L.N.Newall,Brig-Gen.G.0.C, 8th Brigade, 12th April, 1918. Royal Air Force.
